                                                 Draft version June 24, 2020
                                                 Typeset using LATEX twocolumn style in AASTeX63




                                                              GW190814: Gravitational Waves from the Coalescence of a 23 M                         Black Hole
                                                                                  with a 2.6 M Compact Object

                                                                              LIGO Scientific Collaboration and Virgo Collaboration



                                                                                                    (Dated: June 24, 2020)




arXiv:2006.12611v1 [astro-ph.HE] 22 Jun 2020
                                                                                                        ABSTRACT
                                                          We report the observation of a compact binary coalescence involving a 22.2 – 24.3 M black hole and
                                                        a compact object with a mass of 2.50 – 2.67 M (all measurements quoted at the 90% credible level).
                                                        The gravitational-wave signal, GW190814, was observed during LIGO’s and Virgo’s third observing
                                                        run on August 14, 2019 at 21:10:39 UTC and has a signal-to-noise ratio of 25 in the three-detector
                                                        network. The source was localized to 18.5 deg2 at a distance of 241+41          −45 Mpc; no electromagnetic
                                                        counterpart has been confirmed to date. The source has the most unequal mass ratio yet measured
                                                                                         +0.008
                                                        with gravitational waves, 0.112−0.009   , and its secondary component is either the lightest black hole
                                                        or the heaviest neutron star ever discovered in a double compact-object system. The dimensionless
                                                        spin of the primary black hole is tightly constrained to ≤ 0.07. Tests of general relativity reveal no
                                                        measurable deviations from the theory, and its prediction of higher-multipole emission is confirmed at
                                                        high confidence. We estimate a merger rate density of 1–23 Gpc−3 yr−1 for the new class of binary
                                                        coalescence sources that GW190814 represents. Astrophysical models predict that binaries with mass
                                                        ratios similar to this event can form through several channels, but are unlikely to have formed in
                                                        globular clusters. However, the combination of mass ratio, component masses, and the inferred merger
                                                        rate for this event challenges all current models for the formation and mass distribution of compact-
                                                        object binaries.
                                                                  1. INTRODUCTION                                  The first six months of the third observing run (O3)
                                                 The first two observing runs (O1 and O2) with                  were   completed between April 1 and September 30,
                                               Advanced LIGO (Aasi et al. 2015) and Advanced                    2019.   The LVC recently reported on the discovery of
                                               Virgo (Acernese et al. 2015) opened up the field of              GW190425,      the coalescence signal of what is most likely
                                               gravitational-wave astrophysics with the detection of            a  BNS   with   unusually large chirp mass and total mass
                                               the first binary black hole (BBH) coalescence signal,            compared     to  the Galactic BNSs known from radio pul-
                                               GW150914 (Abbott et al. 2016a). Another nine such                sar observations       (Abbott et al. 2020a). Another dis-
                                               events (Abbott et al. 2016b, 2019a) were discovered by           covery from O3 is that of GW190412, the first BBH
                                               the LIGO Scientific and Virgo Collaborations (LVC)               coalescence with an unequivocally unequal mass ratio
                                               during this period, and additional events were reported          q = m2 /m1 of 0.28+0.12  −0.06 (all measurements are reported
                                               by independent groups (Venumadhav et al. 2020; Za-               as symmetric      90%    credible intervals around the median
                                               ckay et al. 2019a,b; Nitz et al. 2020). The first binary         of the  marginalized       posterior distribution, unless other-
                                               neutron star (BNS) coalescence signal, GW170817, was             wise specified).    It  is also the first event for which higher-
                                               discovered during the second of these observing cam-             multipole   gravitational      radiation was detected with high
                                               paigns (Abbott et al. 2017a, 2019b). It proved to be a           significance   (Abbott      et al. 2020d).
                                               multi-messenger source with emission across the electro-            Here  we  report    on   another   O3 detection, GW190814,
                                               magnetic spectrum (Abbott et al. 2017b), with implica-           the signal of a compact binary coalescence with the
                                               tions for the origin of short gamma-ray bursts (Abbott           most unequal mass ratio yet measured with gravitational
                                               et al. 2017c), the formation of heavy elements (Abbott           waves: q = 0.112+0.008 −0.009 . The signal was first identified
                                               et al. 2017d; Chornock et al. 2017; Tanvir et al. 2017;          in data  from   two   detectors,   LIGO Livingston and Virgo,
                                               Rosswog et al. 2018; Kasliwal et al. 2019; Watson et al.         on  2019   August    14,   21:11:00  UTC. Subsequent analysis
                                               2019), cosmology (Abbott et al. 2017e, 2019c) and fun-           of data   from   the   full  three-detector  network revealed a
                                               damental physics (Abbott et al. 2017c, 2019d).                   merger   signal   with    signal-to-noise  ratio (SNR) of ≃ 25.
2

   The primary component of GW190814 is conclusively
                                          +1.1                                                        Normalized energy
a black hole (BH) with mass m1 = 23.2−1.0      M . Its di-
                                                                                      0.0      2.5    5.0    7.5    10.0    12.5       15.0
mensionless spin magnitude is constrained to χ1 ≤ 0.07.
The nature of the 2.59+0.08
                        −0.09 M secondary component is
unclear. The lack of measurable tidal deformations and
the absence of an electromagnetic counterpart are con-                                      LIGO Hanford
sistent with either a neutron star (NS) or a BH given the
event’s asymmetric masses and distance of 241+41                                100
                                                 −45 Mpc.
However, we show here that comparisons with the maxi-
mum NS mass predicted by studies of GW170817’s rem-
nant, by current knowledge of the NS equation of state,
and by electromagnetic observations of NSs in binary                             10
systems indicate that the secondary is likely too heavy
to be a NS. Either way, this is an unprecedented source                                     LIGO Livingston



                                                               Frequency (Hz)
because the secondary’s well-constrained mass of 2.50–
2.67 M makes it either the lightest BH or the heaviest                          100
NS ever observed in a double compact-object system.
   As in the case of GW190412, we are able to measure
the presence of higher multipoles in the gravitational ra-
diation, and a set of tests of general relativity with the                       10
signal reveal no deviations from the theory. Treating
this event as a new class of compact binary coalescences,                                   Virgo
we estimate a merger rate density of 1–23 Gpc−3 yr−1 for
GW190814-like events. Forming coalescing compact bi-                            100
naries with this unusual combination of masses at such a
rate challenges our current understanding of astrophys-
ical models.
   We report on the status of the detector network and                           10
the specifics of the detection in Sections 2 and 3. In                             −10          −8      −6     −4      −2          0

systematic uncertainties. Tests of general relativity are    Figure 1. Time–frequency representations (Chatterji et al.

Table 1. Source properties of GW190814: We report the median values along with the symmetric 90% credible intervals
for the SEOBNRv4PHM (EOBNR PHM) and IMRPhenomPv3HM (Phenom PHM) waveform models. The primary spin
magnitude and the effective precession is given as the 90% upper limit. The inclination angle is folded to [0, π/2]. The last
column is the result of combining the posteriors of each model with equal weight. The sky location of GW190814 is shown in
Figure 2.

  We infer the physical properties of GW190814 using a            Cotesta et al. 2018; Ossokine et al. 2020) and the other
coherent Bayesian analysis of the data from LIGO Liv-             on a phenomenological approach (Phenom; Khan et al.
ingston, LIGO Hanford and Virgo following the method-             2016; Husa et al. 2016; London et al. 2018; Khan et al.
ology described in Appendix B of Abbott et al. (2019a).           2019; Khan et al. 2020).
Results presented here are obtained using 16 s of data              For the NSBH analyses, we use BBH waveform mod-
around the time of detection. We use a low-frequency              els augmented with tidal effects (Matas et al. 2020;
cutoff of 20 Hz for LIGO Hanford and Virgo and 30 Hz              Thompson et al. 2020). Systematic uncertainties due
for LIGO Livingston for the likelihood evaluations, and           to waveform modeling are expected to be subdomi-
we choose uninformative and wide priors, as defined in            nant compared to statistical errors (Huang et al. 2020).
Appendix B.1 of Abbott et al. (2019a). The LALInfer-              When sampling the parameter space with the SEOB-
ence stochastic sampling software (Veitch et al. 2015) is         NRv4 ROM NRTidalv2 NSBH (Matas et al. 2020)
the primary tool used to sample the posterior distribu-           and IMRPhenomNSBH (Thompson et al. 2020) wave-
tion. A parallelized version of the parameter estimation          form models, we obtained posterior distributions for
software bilby (pbilby; Smith & Ashton 2019; Ashton               the secondary component’s tidal deformability Λ2 that
et al. 2019) is used for computationally expensive signal         are uninformative relative to a uniform prior in Λ2 ∈
models. The power spectral density used in the likeli-            [0, 3000]. The absence of a measurable tidal signature is
hood calculations is a fair draw estimate calculated with         consistent with the highly unequal mass ratio (Foucart
BayesWave (Cornish & Littenberg 2015; Littenberg &                et al. 2013; Kumar et al. 2017) and with the relatively
Cornish 2015).                                                    large secondary mass (Flanagan & Hinderer 2008). The
  This signal is analyzed under two different assump-             large asymmetry in the masses implies that the binary
tions: that it represents a BBH, or that it represents a          will merge before the neutron star is tidally disrupted for
NSBH. For the BBH analyses, two different waveform                any expected NS equation of state (Foucart et al. 2013).
families are used, one based on the effective-one-body            Given that the signal carries no discernible information
approach (EOBNR; Bohé et al. 2017; Babak et al. 2017;

sults only from BBH waveform models.                                          nou 2020). The inferred secondary mass is comparable

Figure 3. A summary of the inferred source prop-
                                                                                 The time delay of a signal across a network of gravi-
erties is given in Table 1. We assume a standard

                                                                                 Spins are a fundamental property of BHs. Their mag-
that one waveform family is preferred over the other as
                                                                              nitude and orientation carry information regarding the
the Bayes factor between Phenom PHM and EOBNR
                                                                              evolution history of the binary. The effective inspiral
PHM is log10 B ≃ 1.0. As a result, we combine the

posterior samples with equal weight, in effect marginal-
                                                                              et al. 2011; Santamarı́a et al. 2010) contains informa-
izing over a discrete set of signal models with a uniform
                                                                              tion about the spin components that are perpendicular
probability. This is shown in the last column of Table 1,
                                                                              to the orbital plane. We infer that χeff = −0.002+0.060−0.061 .
and we refer to these values throughout the paper unless

stated otherwise.

range 2.50– 2.67 M . This inferred secondary mass

exceeds the bounds of the primary component in

GW190425 (1.61–2.52 M ; Abbott et al. 2020a) and the
                                                                              effective precession spin parameter 0 ≤ χp ≤ 1 (Schmidt
most massive known pulsar in the Galaxy: 2.14+0.10

thermore, the secondary is more massive than bounds

eral null tests of GR using GW190814. These tests as-         primary and secondary compact objects in the binary.
sume GW190814 is a (quasi-circular) BBH merger as de-         Since κ1 and κ2 are strongly degenerate in the gravita-
scribed in GR, and look for inconsistencies between the       tional waveform, we instead measure a linear symmetric

of the underlying signal (or noise), and could indicate a     tively uninformative, and nearly span the prior range
non-BBH nature of the signal or a potential departure         of [0, 500], with increased support at κs = 0 relative to
from GR.                                                      the prior. The upper bound of the prior was chosen to

                6.1. Merger Rate Density                            for the class of mergers represented by GW190814 is
  Given the unprecedented combination of component                  primarily dominated by Poisson statistics.
masses found in GW190814, we take the system to rep-
resent a new class of compact binary mergers, and use                      6.2. Nature of the Secondary Component
our analysis of its source properties to estimate a merger
rate density for GW190814-like events. Following a                    The primary mass measurement of 23.2+1.1    −1.0 M   se-
method described in Kim et al. (2003), we calculate                 curely identifies the heavier component of GW190814 as
a simple, single-event rate density estimate R accord-              a BH, but the secondary mass of 2.59+0.08
                                                                                                            −0.09 M may be

ing to our sensitivity to a population of systems drawn             compatible with either a NS or a BH depending on the
from the parameter-estimation posteriors. As in Ab-                 maximum mass supported by the unknown NS equa-
bott et al. (2020a), we calculate our surveyed space-               tion of state (EOS). The source’s asymmetric masses,
time volume hV T i semi-analytically, imposing single-              the non-detection of an electromagnetic counterpart and
detector and network SNR thresholds of 5 and 10, re-                the lack of a clear signature of tides or spin-induced
spectively (Tiwari 2018). The semi-analytic hV T i for              quadrupole effects in the waveform do not allow us to
GW190814 is then multiplied by a calibration factor to              distinguish between a BBH or a NSBH. Instead, we rely
match results from the search pipelines assuming a once-            on comparisons between m2 and different estimates of
per-century FAR threshold. The sensitivity of a search              the maximum NS mass, Mmax , to indicate the source
pipeline is estimated using a set of simulated signals.             classification preferred by data: if m2 > Mmax , then the
For computational efficiency, this was done using pre-              NSBH scenario is untenable.
existing search pipeline simulations and the mass prop-               While some candidate EOSs from nuclear theory can
erties were not highly optimized. However, given that               support nonrotating NSs with masses of up to ∼ 3 M
we are estimating a rate based on a single source, the cal-         (e.g., Müller & Serot 1996), such large values of Mmax

2.3 M . Similarly, the EOS inference reported in Abbott         Finally, the NS maximum mass is constrained by stud-

(2018) by reconstructing each EOS from its parameters        tion. Assuming this ultimate fate for the merger rem-
and computing its maximum mass. Comparison with              nant immediately implies that no NS can be stable above

marginalized over the uncertainty in m2 and Mmax , is        nant to Mmax depends on the EOS, but by developing
only 3%. Nevertheless, the maximum mass predictions          approximate prescriptions based on sequences of rapidly

population of NSs in binaries to a double-Gaussian mass         There are two further caveats to this assessment.
distribution with a high-mass cutoff, Alsing et al. (2018)   First, because the secondary’s spin is unconstrained, it
obtained an empirical constraint of Mmax ≤ 2.6 M             could conceivably be rotating rapidly enough for m2
(one-sided 90% confidence interval). Farr & Chatzi-          to exceed Mmax without triggering gravitational col-
ioannou (2020) recently updated this analysis to in-         lapse: rapid uniform rotation can stabilize a star up

which is plotted in the right panel of Figure 3, we          pating such extreme natal NS spin angular momentum.
find Mmax = 2.25+0.81

probability of m2 ≤ Mmax is 29%, again favoring the          sibility that the secondary component is an exotic com-
m2 > Mmax scenario, albeit less strongly because of the      pact object, such as a boson star (Kaup 1968) or a
distribution’s long tail up to ∼ 3 M . However, the em-      gravastar (Mazur & Mottola 2004), instead of a NS or a
pirical Mmax prediction is sensitive to selection effects    BH. Depending on the model, some exotic compact ob-
that could potentially bias it (Alsing et al. 2018). In      jects can potentially support masses up to and beyond
                                                                                                                      13

                                                              tions of a few candidates with masses in this range seem
                                                              to disfavor the existence of a gap (Freire et al. 2008;
                                                              Neustroev et al. 2014; Giesers et al. 2018; Wyrzykowski
                                                              & Mandel 2020; Thompson et al. 2019), but whether the
                                                              mass gap is physical or caused by selection biases is still
                                                              a matter of debate (e.g., Kreidberg et al. 2012).
                                                                 From a theoretical point of view, accurately calculat-
                                                              ing the masses of compact remnants at formation is chal-
                                                              lenging, because it depends on the complex physics of
                                                              the supernova explosion and the details of stellar evolu-
                                                              tion, especially for the late evolutionary stages of mas-
                                                              sive stars (Janka 2012; Müller 2016; Burrows et al. 2018;
                                                              Burrows et al. 2019). Whether the models favor the

was produced by a BBH (blue) or a NSBH (orange) coales-       and BHs is still unclear, and in fact some models have

in the pressure-density plane are shown. The constraints

EOS, following Abbott et al. (2018). The BBH constraints

dashed lines indicate the 90% credible region of the prior.   fact, GW190814 demonstrates the need to adjust rem-
